Furthermore, the safety of raw milk is well-documented when it comes from clean, healthy animals and is handled properly. In contrast, pasteurized milk often comes from industrial farming operations where the use of antibiotics, growth hormones, and poor animal conditions can compromise the quality of the milk.

| **High‑temperature, short‑time (HTST)** | 72 °C (161 °F) for 15 s (most commercial milk) | Destroys >99.9 % of disease‑causing microbes; retains most proteins, calcium, vitamin D |
| **Ultra‑high‑temperature (UHT)** | 135–150 °C (275–302 °F) for 2–5 s | Sterilises milk, extends shelf‑life; slight loss of some heat‑sensitive vitamins (e.g., vitamin C, B‑complex) but these are present in very small amounts in milk anyway |

| **World Health Organization (WHO) – Food Safety** | Pasteurisation is the globally endorsed method to make milk safe; WHO advises **against** raw‑milk consumption for the general public. |
